q: What is the 'First Rule of ARIA'?
o: If you can use a native HTML element with the semantics and behavior you require, do so instead of repurposing an element and adding an ARIA role

q: Which organization maintains the ARIA specification?

o: A simpler way to define what an element is (e.g., button, dialog, slider)
Provides a label for an element that overrides its text content for assistive technology
References the ID of another element to define its label
References the ID of an element that provides a description (more info than a label)
Removes the element and its children from the accessibility tree (ignored by screen readers), but keeps it visible

q: When should you use 'role="button"' on a div?
o: Only when you cannot use a native <button> tag for some reason

q: If you use 'role="button"' on a div, what else must you do?
o: Make it focusable with tabindex="0" and handle Enter/Space key events
A role that identifies a significant region of the page (banner, main, navigation, etc.)

Indicates the state of a checkbox, radio button, or switch

No, presentation is for images only

q: Does 'role="presentation"' hide the text content inside the element?
o: No, text content remains accessible; only the element's semantic container role is removed
Indicates usage of an element has failed validation
Indicates that user input is required on the element

q: Can you use ARIA roles on any HTML element?
o: No, there are rules about which roles are computed/allowed on which elements (ARIA in HTML spec)

q: What is the primary difference between 'role="menu"' and 'role="listbox"'?
o: Menu contains actions (menuitems); Listbox contains selectable data items (options)
Menu is vertical; Listbox is horizontal
Menu is for navigation; Listbox is for searching

q: When using 'aria-activedescendant', what must the container element have?
o: Focus (or be the active element) and appropriate role (e.g., combobox, listbox)
Indicates to assistive technologies that the element is a modal dialog and background content should be obscured/ignored

q: What must you do with keyboard focus when a modal opens?
o: Leave focus on the trigger button

q: What must you do with keyboard focus when a modal closes?
o: Return focus to the element that triggered the modal (or a logical alternative)

q: What is 'focus trapping' in a modal?
o: Constraining the Tab cycle so focus stays within the modal content while it is open

q: What is the difference between HTML 'disabled' attribute and 'aria-disabled'?

q: What is 'Strong Native Semantics' rule regarding ARIA?
o: You cannot override semantics of certain elements (e.g. <input type='text'> cannot be role='list')

q: If you put a heading inside a button ``, is it a heading?
o: No, the heading semantic is stripped because button children are presentational

q: What is 'accessible name from content' vs 'from author'?
o: Author leads (aria-label/labelledby); Content follows (inner text). aria-label overrides content

q: What is 'Name from content' limitation on inputs?
o: Inputs (textbox) don't compute name from inner text/value; they need explicit label or aria-label

o: None; never put aria-hidden=true on a focusable element (validity error)
